text: Japanese tea masters prized the simple, unpretentious beauty of everyday wares produced by Korean émigré potters at the Karatsu kilns on the southern-most island of Kyushu. This small cup-shaped dish, called mukōzuke, was used to serve an appetizer of marinated fish or vegetables. The term mukōzuke describes their placement (zuke) on the opposite side (mukō) of the serving tray--away from the guest. Bowls for rice and soup were placed closer to the guest on the tray. Typical of wares from the Karatsu kilns, this mukōzuke was decorated with casual, rapidly painted designs in iron-oxide brown.
title: Individual serving vessel (mukōzuke)
